segment.source: Configure devices without MDM (Windows 10)
segment.target: Configure devices without MDM (Windows 10)

segment.source: Create a runtime provisioning package to apply settings, profiles, and file assets to a device running Windows 10.
segment.target: Create a runtime provisioning package to apply settings, profiles, and file assets to a device running Windows 10.

segment.source: Configure devices without MDM
segment.target: Configure devices without MDM

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile

segment.source: Create a runtime provisioning package to apply settings, profiles, and file assets to a device running Windows 10 Pro, Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows 10 Education, Windows 10 Mobile, or Windows 10 Mobile Enterprise.
segment.target: Create a runtime provisioning package to apply settings, profiles, and file assets to a device running Windows 10 Pro, Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows 10 Education, Windows 10 Mobile, or Windows 10 Mobile Enterprise.

segment.source: Sometimes mobile device management (MDM) isn't available to you for setting up a device because the device isn't connected to your network, or because an employee is remote and needs a fast replacement for a work device.
segment.target: Sometimes mobile device management (MDM) isn't available to you for setting up a device because the device isn't connected to your network, or because an employee is remote and needs a fast replacement for a work device.

segment.source: You might not use MDM in your organization at all, but would like an easy way to place a standard configuration on multiple devices.
segment.target: You might not use MDM in your organization at all, but would like an easy way to place a standard configuration on multiple devices.

segment.source: Rather than wiping a device and applying a new system image, in Windows 10 you can apply a provisioning package at any time.
segment.target: Rather than wiping a device and applying a new system image, in Windows 10 you can apply a provisioning package at any time.

segment.source: A provisioning package can include management instructions and policies, installation of specific apps, customization of network connections and policies, and more.
segment.target: A provisioning package can include management instructions and policies, installation of specific apps, customization of network connections and policies, and more.

segment.source: You can provide provisioning packages on a network shared folder that employees can access to configure their devices.
segment.target: You can provide provisioning packages on a network shared folder that employees can access to configure their devices.

segment.source: Or you can put a provisioning package on a USB flash drive or SD card to hand out.
segment.target: Or you can put a provisioning package on a USB flash drive or SD card to hand out.

segment.source: You can even send the provisioning package to someone in email.
segment.target: You can even send the provisioning package to someone in email.

segment.source: Provisioning packages are simple for employees to install.
segment.target: Provisioning packages are simple for employees to install.

segment.source: And when they remove a provisioning package, policies that the package applied to their device are removed.
segment.target: And when they remove a provisioning package, policies that the package applied to their device are removed.

segment.source: Advantages
segment.target: Advantages

segment.source: You can configure new devices without re-imaging.
segment.target: You can configure new devices without re-imaging.

segment.source: Works on both mobile and desktop devices.
segment.target: Works on both mobile and desktop devices.

segment.source: No network connectivity required.
segment.target: No network connectivity required.

segment.source: Simple for people to apply.
segment.target: Simple for people to apply.

segment.source: Ensures compliance and security before a device is enrolled in MDM.
segment.target: Ensures compliance and security before a device is enrolled in MDM.

segment.source: Typical use cases
segment.target: Typical use cases

segment.source: Set up a new off-the-shelf device for an employee
segment.target: Set up a new off-the-shelf device for an employee

segment.source: Package might include edition upgrade, device name, company root certificate, Wi-Fi profile, domain join with service account, or company application.
segment.target: Package might include edition upgrade, device name, company root certificate, Wi-Fi profile, domain join with service account, or company application.

segment.source: Configure an off-the-shelf mobile device to be used as a point of sale or inventory terminal
segment.target: Configure an off-the-shelf mobile device to be used as a point of sale or inventory terminal

segment.source: Package might include edition upgrade, device name, company root certificate, Wi-Fi profile, security policies, company application, or assigned access (also known as kiosk mode.
segment.target: Package might include edition upgrade, device name, company root certificate, Wi-Fi profile, security policies, company application, or assigned access (also known as kiosk mode.

segment.source: Help employees set up personally-owned devices to use for work
segment.target: Help employees set up personally-owned devices to use for work

segment.source: Package might include company root certificate, Wi-Fi profiles, security policies, or company application.
segment.target: Package might include company root certificate, Wi-Fi profiles, security policies, or company application.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Test to make sure that removing the provisioning package from a personal device removes everything that the package installed.
segment.target: Test to make sure that removing the provisioning package from a personal device removes everything that the package installed.

segment.source: Some settings are not reverted when a provisioning package is removed from the device.
segment.target: Some settings are not reverted when a provisioning package is removed from the device.

segment.source: Repurpose devices by returning the device to a specific state between users
segment.target: Repurpose devices by returning the device to a specific state between users

segment.source: Package might include computer name, company root certificate, Wi-Fi profile, or company application.
segment.target: Package might include computer name, company root certificate, Wi-Fi profile, or company application.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To return the Start menu to a specific state, you must reset the device.
segment.target: To return the Start menu to a specific state, you must reset the device.

segment.source: When you reset the device, you can apply the provisioning package during the first-run experience.
segment.target: When you reset the device, you can apply the provisioning package during the first-run experience.

segment.source: For details about the settings you can customize in provisioning packages, see Windows Provisioning settings reference.
segment.target: For details about the settings you can customize in provisioning packages, see Windows Provisioning settings reference.

segment.source: Create package
segment.target: Create package

segment.source: Use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) tool included in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows 10 to create a runtime provisioning package.
segment.target: Use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) tool included in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows 10 to create a runtime provisioning package.

segment.source: Install the ADK.
segment.target: Install the ADK.

segment.source: Open Windows ICD (by default, %windir%Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitImaging and Configuration Designerx86ICD.exe).
segment.target: Open Windows ICD (by default, %windir%Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitImaging and Configuration Designerx86ICD.exe).

segment.source: Choose New provisioning package.
segment.target: Choose New provisioning package.

segment.source: Name your project, and click Next.
segment.target: Name your project, and click Next.

segment.source: Choose Common to all Windows editions, Common to all Windows desktop editions, or Common to all Windows mobile editions, depending on the devices you intend to provision, and click Next.
segment.target: Choose Common to all Windows editions, Common to all Windows desktop editions, or Common to all Windows mobile editions, depending on the devices you intend to provision, and click Next.

segment.source: On New project, click Finish.
segment.target: On New project, click Finish.

segment.source: The workspace for your package opens.
segment.target: The workspace for your package opens.

segment.source: Configure settings.
segment.target: Configure settings.

segment.source: Learn more about specific settings in provisioning packages.
segment.target: Learn more about specific settings in provisioning packages.

segment.source: On the File menu, select Save.
segment.target: On the File menu, select Save.

segment.source: On the Export menu, select Provisioning package.
segment.target: On the Export menu, select Provisioning package.

segment.source: Change Owner to IT Admin, which will set the precedence of this provisioning package higher than provisioning packages applied to this device from other sources, and then select Next.
segment.target: Change Owner to IT Admin, which will set the precedence of this provisioning package higher than provisioning packages applied to this device from other sources, and then select Next.

segment.source: Set a value for Package Version.
segment.target: Set a value for Package Version.

segment.source: Tip
segment.target: Tip

segment.source: You can make changes to existing packages and change the version number to update previously applied packages.
segment.target: You can make changes to existing packages and change the version number to update previously applied packages.

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: In the Provisioning package security window, you can choose to encrypt the package and enable package signing.
segment.target: In the Provisioning package security window, you can choose to encrypt the package and enable package signing.

segment.source: Enable package encryption - If you select this option, an auto-generated password will be shown on the screen.
segment.target: Enable package encryption - If you select this option, an auto-generated password will be shown on the screen.

segment.source: Enable package signing - If you select this option, you must select a valid certificate to use for signing the package.
segment.target: Enable package signing - If you select this option, you must select a valid certificate to use for signing the package.

segment.source: You can specify the certificate by clicking Select... and choosing the certificate you want to use to sign the package.
segment.target: You can specify the certificate by clicking Select... and choosing the certificate you want to use to sign the package.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: We recommend that you include a trusted provisioning certificate in your provisioning package.
segment.target: We recommend that you include a trusted provisioning certificate in your provisioning package.

segment.source: When the package is applied to a device, the certificate is added to the system store and any package signed with that certificate thereafter can be applied silently.
segment.target: When the package is applied to a device, the certificate is added to the system store and any package signed with that certificate thereafter can be applied silently.

segment.source: Click Next to specify the output location where you want the provisioning package to go once it's built.
segment.target: Click Next to specify the output location where you want the provisioning package to go once it's built.

segment.source: By default, Windows ICD uses the project folder as the output location.
segment.target: By default, Windows ICD uses the project folder as the output location.

segment.source: Optionally, you can click Browse to change the default output location.
segment.target: Optionally, you can click Browse to change the default output location.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Click Build to start building the package.
segment.target: Click Build to start building the package.

segment.source: The project information is displayed in the build page and the progress bar indicates the build status.
segment.target: The project information is displayed in the build page and the progress bar indicates the build status.

segment.source: If you need to cancel the build, click Cancel.
segment.target: If you need to cancel the build, click Cancel.

segment.source: This cancels the current build process, closes the wizard, and takes you back to the Customizations Page.
segment.target: This cancels the current build process, closes the wizard, and takes you back to the Customizations Page.

segment.source: If your build fails, an error message will show up that includes a link to the project folder.
segment.target: If your build fails, an error message will show up that includes a link to the project folder.

segment.source: You can scan the logs to determine what caused the error.
segment.target: You can scan the logs to determine what caused the error.

segment.source: Once you fix the issue, try building the package again.
segment.target: Once you fix the issue, try building the package again.

segment.source: If your build is successful, the name of the provisioning package, output directory, and project directory will be shown.
segment.target: If your build is successful, the name of the provisioning package, output directory, and project directory will be shown.

segment.source: If you choose, you can build the provisioning package again and pick a different path for the output package.
segment.target: If you choose, you can build the provisioning package again and pick a different path for the output package.

segment.source: To do this, click Back to change the output package name and path, and then click Next to start another build.
segment.target: To do this, click Back to change the output package name and path, and then click Next to start another build.

segment.source: If you are done, click Finish to close the wizard and go back to the Customizations Page.
segment.target: If you are done, click Finish to close the wizard and go back to the Customizations Page.

segment.source: Select the output location link to go to the location of the package.
segment.target: Select the output location link to go to the location of the package.

segment.source: You can provide that .ppkg to others through any of the following methods:
segment.target: You can provide that .ppkg to others through any of the following methods:

segment.source: Shared network folder
segment.target: Shared network folder

segment.source: SharePoint site
segment.target: SharePoint site

segment.source: Removable media (USB/SD)
segment.target: Removable media (USB/SD)

segment.source: Email
segment.target: Email

segment.source: USB tether (mobile only)
segment.target: USB tether (mobile only)

segment.source: Learn more: Build and apply a provisioning package
segment.target: Learn more: Build and apply a provisioning package

segment.source: Apply package
segment.target: Apply package

segment.source: On a desktop computer, the employee goes to SettingsAccountsWork accessAdd or remove a management packageAdd a package, and selects the package to install.
segment.target: On a desktop computer, the employee goes to SettingsAccountsWork accessAdd or remove a management packageAdd a package, and selects the package to install.

segment.source: The user can also add a provisioning package simply by double-clicking the .ppkg file in email, in local storage, on removable media, or at a URL.
segment.target: The user can also add a provisioning package simply by double-clicking the .ppkg file in email, in local storage, on removable media, or at a URL.

segment.source: add a package option
segment.target: add a package option

segment.source: On a mobile device, the employee goes to SettingsAccountsProvisioning.
segment.target: On a mobile device, the employee goes to SettingsAccountsProvisioning.

segment.source: Add a package, and selects the package on removable media to install.
segment.target: Add a package, and selects the package on removable media to install.

segment.source: The user can also add a provisioning package simply by double-tapping the .ppkg file in email.
segment.target: The user can also add a provisioning package simply by double-tapping the .ppkg file in email.

segment.source: add provisioning package on phone
segment.target: add provisioning package on phone

segment.source: Manage a package
segment.target: Manage a package

segment.source: Users can view details or delete package (if policy allows deletion); only user-installed packages are listed.
segment.target: Users can view details or delete package (if policy allows deletion); only user-installed packages are listed.

segment.source: Deleting a package removes settings, profiles, certificates, and apps it contains.
segment.target: Deleting a package removes settings, profiles, certificates, and apps it contains.

segment.source: Use policies to disable manual deletion of packages, installation of unsigned packages, or the installation of any additional packages.
segment.target: Use policies to disable manual deletion of packages, installation of unsigned packages, or the installation of any additional packages.

segment.source: Update content by installing a new package with same name and new version number.
segment.target: Update content by installing a new package with same name and new version number.

segment.source: Optionally, keep packages when you reset a mobile device.
segment.target: Optionally, keep packages when you reset a mobile device.

segment.source: When you reset a desktop, runtime packages are removed.
segment.target: When you reset a desktop, runtime packages are removed.

segment.source: Learn more
segment.target: Learn more

segment.source: Provisioning Windows 10 Devices with New Tools
segment.target: Provisioning Windows 10 Devices with New Tools

segment.source: Windows 10 for Mobile Devices: Provisioning Is Not Imaging
segment.target: Windows 10 for Mobile Devices: Provisioning Is Not Imaging
